1120654371388178432.text:
Division can be defined by writing n = q * d + r with q as large as possible and 0 <= r < d. Choosing "n/d = q" and "n%d = r" seem like reasonable definitions for a programming language, and mathematics in general.

For reals, the "q as large as possible" sets "r = 0".https://twitter.com/rg9119/status/1120423023226626048 …

1113033627921571840.text:
What are all the good generalizations of boolean "or" to floating points in [0,1]?

FloatBools have at least 3 properties:

(or 1.0 x) = 1.0
(or 0.0 x) = x
(or x y) >= (max x y)

Saying "or = max" satisfies these, as does "x and y are independent events":

(1-(1-x)*(1-y))

Independency-friendly logic gives you more control over which variables depend on other variables.

forall x. exists y. forall z/{y}. P(x,y,Z)

The "z/{y}" excludes y from the dependencies of z:
y = Y(x)
z = Z(x)

1111182208469864448.text:
In first-order logic, you accumulate more variable bindings going from left to right:

forall x. exists y. forall z. P(x,y,z)

z is allowed to depend on x,y. And y depends on x:

y = Y(x)
z = Z(x,y)

for Skolem functions Y,Z.

1. identity . HASH
2. negate . HASH

are also irreversible. But if #1 is "mixed" with a XOR, the resulting function will always hash to 0. And #2 would leave it unchanged.

So you'd have to prove the hash functions are uncorrelated.

How to implement toInteger for any type T in Haskell.

1. Save /proc/$$/mem into a Bytestring somewhere
2. Evaluate x :: T
3. Save /proc/$$/mem again
4. Diff the bytestrings to produce a finite sequence of bits
5. Interpret bits as an unsigned integer.

1024013395152912385.text:
Made a little profiling library.

Instead of: (f x)
Use: (traced f x)
Or: (checkpoint f x)

A trace is supposed to be a tiny unit of progress, while a checkpoint is a step on the larger data structure.

If too much time elapses between traces, it warns of "unaccounted time".

1005685363396902917.text:
(U ERROR X) can always be simplified to X.
But (U ⊥ X) cannot be simplified without making the extra assumption that the expression completes execution normally(such as with an annotation).

1005684350275366914.text:
Both bottom types are absorbing elements, but ERROR takes priority:

1. Unify(⊥, X) = ⊥
2. Unify(ERROR, X) = ERROR
3. Unify(⊥, ERROR) = ERROR

⊥ is the type of explicit exceptions/control transfers.
ERROR is the type of inhabited types reduced to the empty set by Unify.

1005683080361738240.text:
⊥ being the empty set is fine for type inference.

But I stated earlier that "goto", "throw exception", "invoke continuation", etc. all have the ⊥ type. So should a program be rejected that passes "goto (label 'foo)" to a λ?

There could be two different bottom types: ⊥, ERROR

1005681572694056960.text:
I think what I want is:
1. Unify(T1, T2) calculates the intersection type of T1, T2; with the restriction that it must be inhabited.
2. A Constraint Type "X <: TYPE" can be generated if "x ∈ ~TYPE implies (∩ T1 T2) <: ⊥".

~X is the set complement of X, not "X implies False".

1005677845937418240.text:
The former seems like it would run into decidability issues.
The latter have more complex semantics when dealing with subtyping. And probably give worse error messages.

1005677332500176897.text:
Two models of type unification:

1. Unification selects types for type variables that makes the type formulae equal as sets.

2. All type variables are assigned TOP to start. Constraints are really a giant type intersection, which reduces the possibilities to the smallest set.

1005669698162212864.text:
Unify(T1, T2) calculates a set of type variable substitutions SUB s.t. SUB(T1) <: SUB(T2) and SUB(T2) <: SUB(T1).

U := Intersect(T1,T2) is the largest subtype of both.

Unify(Intersect(T1, U), Intersect(T2, U)) should always succeed with no constraints, but Unify(T1,T2) can fail

O(n^k) is the set of programs with k for loops.
O(k^n) is the set of recursive programs that call themselves k times.

P != NP asks if these sets of programs are somehow equal, but

2. Not every recursive program has a for loop.

QED.

1003339603695185920.text:
Intersection types arise from union types when a value can be obtained from multiple branches. So they can be used to simulate a propositional AND.

f := (\x -> if x T1 T2) : (-> Boolean (U T1 T2))
y = f True : T1
y = f False : T2

⊦ y : (∩ T1 T2)

1003335930017484800.text:
An "if" statement naturally branches into a union type.

A Haskell "case" statement branches into a sum type because it checks each case in-order. So later cases can assume that earlier cases are false.

But, this doesn't preserve the Closed World Assumption, so "case" is unsafe.

1003333849500119040.text:
If "data X = A | B" and "data Y = X | C", then there is an implicit type "data Z = A | B | C" that factors X/Y into primitive constructors.

Perhaps sum types should be preferred at the leaves, and union types should be preferred at branches?

1003333227501637632.text:
Union and intersection types are the "transparent"/"forgetful" versions of sum and product types.

A sum type 'data X = A | B' "remembers" which branch it came from.
A product type 'data X = X (A, B)' "remembers" both proofs of A and B.

1003329523264339968.text:
Union types = T1 OR T2 = (U T1 T2)
Intersection types = T1 AND T2 (∩ T1 T2)
